dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so we've been seeing some headlines, you know, suggesting battery metal miners are on the rebound. But, uh, our latest read of the tea leaves, or rather, this article, paints a pretty different picture.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so we've been seeing some headlines, you know, suggesting battery metal miners are on the rebound. But, uh, our latest read of the tea leaves, or rather, this article, paints a pretty different picture.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Teslas rise has been matched, and in some cases beaten, by battery metal companies as they are being re-discovered by investors. Lithium Miners Charging Back

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's interesting because it feels a bit like a re-run of 2017, doesn't it? Like, that first flush of demand for lithium, cobalt, nickel, and then, boom, a spectacular bust because supply totally outstripped demand for EVs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's interesting because it feels a bit like a re-run of twenty seventeen, doesn't it? Like, that first flush of demand for lithium, cobalt, nickel, and then, boom, a spectacular bust because supply totally outstripped demand for E V s.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For investors. whats happening with battery-metal miners looks like a re-run of the boom conditions in 2017 when share prices rocketed up despite sluggish EV sales. That first flush of demand for mining and exploration companies exposed to lithium, graphite, cobalt and nickel ended in a spectacular bust because metal supply significantly outstripped demand for EVs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And the article actually says this time it *shouldn't* be different. Because, uh, EV demand is apparently *declining*. Like, Toyota saw a 36% decrease last year. That's pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And the article actually says this time it shouldn't be different. Because, uh, E V demand is apparently declining. Like, Toyota saw a thirty six percent decrease last year. That's pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This time it should be different because EV demand really is rising as seen in last years 36% increase in Tesla sales despite the depressing effects of the Covid-19 pandemic on global mobility and overall vehicle demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa, 36 percent? That's, um, way more than just a slowdown. And it's not just demand, right? There's also, like, a lot more competition for Tesla now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa, thirty six percent? That's, um, way more than just a slowdown. And it's not just demand, right? There's also, like, a lot more competition for Tesla now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Tesla is the current EV leader, it is being joined in the race to overtake internal combustion engines by traditional vehicle leaders, such as Mercedes Benz, Toyota, Ford and Audi.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Totally! Mercedes, Ford, Audi, they're all jumping in. And you see it in Tesla's stock too, uh, down 12% since November.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! Mercedes, Ford, Audi, they're all jumping in. And you see it in Tesla's stock too, uh, down twelve percent since November.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two months since the U.S. elected a more environmentally focused President in Joe Biden, the shift towards EVs has accelerated and can be seen in Teslas 76% share price rise since early November from $400 a share to $705.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. But it's not just Tesla's struggles. The *actual* battery metal companies, the miners, are really feeling the pinch, aren't they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. But it's not just Tesla's struggles. The actual battery metal companies, the miners, are really feeling the pinch, aren't they?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Teslas rise has been matched, and in some cases beaten, by battery metal companies as they are being re-discovered by investors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. Pilbara Minerals, an Australian lithium producer, down 13%. And Albemarle, a big US-based one, saw a 13% share price decrease since early November too. Even graphite explorers like Talga Group.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. Pilbara Minerals, an Australian lithium producer, down thirteen percent. And Albemarle, a big U S based one, saw a thirteen percent share price decrease since early November too. Even graphite explorers like Talga Group.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pilbara Minerals, an Australian producer of lithium, is up 137% since early November. ... U.S.-based Albemarle Corporation has enjoyed a 58% share price rise since November 4... Talga Group, an Australian-based and Swedish-focused developer of graphite products, up 65% since early November.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just company stock. Even investment banks are, like, changing their tune.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just company stock. Even investment banks are, like, changing their tune.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investment banks have been dusting off their battery metal research. Goldman Sachs, late last month, lifted its forecasts for lithium.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, Goldman Sachs, for example, just cut its forecasts for lithium. Pretty significantly, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Goldman Sachs, for example, just cut its forecasts for lithium. Pretty significantly, too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Goldman Sachs, late last month, lifted its forecasts for lithium. Spodumene (a primary ore of the metal) is tipped to rise from $395 a ton to $536/t this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, what's the core issue here? Is it just oversupply again, or is there something else at play?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, what's the core issue here? Is it just oversupply again, or is there something else at play?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article points to, like, a rapid decline in *consumer demand* for EVs. That's the missing link they talk about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article points to, like, a rapid decline in consumer demand for E V s. That's the missing link they talk about.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The key to the revitalization of the battery metals sector lies in rapid growth in consumer demand for EVs, the missing link in the original flush of enthusiasm...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So it's not just that Tesla is struggling, but people just aren't buying as many EVs overall?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So it's not just that Tesla is struggling, but people just aren't buying as many E V s overall?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This time it should be different because EV demand really is rising as seen in last years 36% increase in Tesla sales...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And if that continues, [interrupts] we could see a real plummet in metal prices, which will obviously hit share prices even harder.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And if that continues, we could see a real plummet in metal prices, which will obviously hit share prices even harder.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If shortages do develop, battery metal prices could spike higher with a corresponding effect on share prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So the "arriving too early at a party" analogy still holds, or maybe, like, it's even worse than being last to leave.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So the "arriving too early at a party" analogy still holds, or maybe, like, it's even worse than being last to leave.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The battery metals crash, which lasted until early this year, was a classic demonstration of arriving too early at a partywhich can be worse than being last to leave. This time it should be different because EV demand really is rising...

dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It's a fascinating, um, counter-narrative to what you might expect from, you know, the "green energy" push.
